answer_html: \(J(1,2)=\begin{pmatrix} -1 -1 \\ 2 -2 \end{pmatrix}.\) The eigenvalues satisfy the characteristic polynomial \(\lambda^2 + 3 \lambda + 4 = 0\) so \(\lambda^\pm = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9 - 16}}{2} = -3/2 \pm \sqrt{7} i/2.\) These eigenvalues have a nonzero imaginary part giving rise to a spiral/ellipse. As there real components are negative, we have a stable spiral at (1,2).

hints_html:
At a critical point, both dx/dt and dy/dt must be 0. Be careful to consider all possible cases.

To determine the stability, consider the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix

\[\begin{aligned} J = \begin{pmatrix} f_x & f_y \\ g_x & g_y \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
At a critical point, both dx/dt and dy/dt must be 0. Be careful to
consider all possible cases.
hints_raw:
At a critical point, both dx/dt and dy/dt must be 0. Be careful to consider all possible cases.
To determine the stability, consider the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix
:<math>J = \begin{pmatrix} f_x & f_y \\ g_x & g_y \end{pmatrix}</math>
question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
__NOTOC__ If \(\displaystyle x' = 0\) then either \(x=0\) or \(x=3-y\).

  • Using \(\displaystyle x = 0\) in \(y' = 0\) we get \(y=0,1\). This gives two critical points: (0,0) and (0,1).

  • Using \(\displaystyle x=3-y\) in \(y' = 0\) we get \(y=0,2\). In this case, x=3 when y=0, and x=1 when y=2. This gives two more critical points (1,2) and (3,0).

Considering the full system, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix} x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3x - x^2 - xy \\ y + xy - y^2 \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Labelling \(\displaystyle f(x,y) = 3x - x^2 - xy\) and \(\displaystyle g(x,y) = y + xy - y^2\), the Jacobian of the system at \((x,y)\) is

\[\begin{aligned} J = \begin{pmatrix} f_x & f_y \\ g_x & g_y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 - 2x - y & -x \\ y & 1 + x - 2y \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

The Jacobian evaluated at the critical points gives us information about the local stability of the critical points.

At (x,y) = (0,0)

\[\begin{aligned} J(0,0) = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which has eigenvalues of +1 and +3. Thus (0,0) is an unstable node (both eigenvalues are real and positive).

At (x,y) = (0,1)

\[\begin{aligned} J(0,1) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which has eigenvalues of +2 and -1 (being lower triangular, the eigenvalues are the diagonal entries). As the eigenvalues are real and of opposite sign, (0,1) is a saddle point.

At (x,y) = (3,0)

\[\begin{aligned} J(3,0) = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & -3 \\ 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

having eigenvalues of -3 and +4 (the matrix is upper triangular and its eigenvalues are the diagonal entries). We thus have (3,0) is a saddle point.

At (x,y) = (1,2)

\[\begin{aligned} J(1,2) = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

The eigenvalues satisfy the characteristic polynomial \(\lambda^2 + 3 \lambda + 4 = 0\) so \(\lambda^\pm = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9 - 16}}{2} = -3/2 \pm \sqrt{7} i/2.\) These eigenvalues have a nonzero imaginary part giving rise to a spiral/ellipse. As there real components are negative, we have a stable spiral at (1,2).
sols_raw:
__NOTOC__
If <math>\displaystyle x' = 0</math> then either <math>x=0</math> or <math>x=3-y</math>.

* Using <math>\displaystyle x = 0</math> in <math>y' = 0</math> we get <math>y=0,1</math>. This gives two critical points: (0,0) and (0,1).
* Using <math>\displaystyle x=3-y</math> in <math>y' = 0</math> we get <math>y=0,2</math>. In this case, ''x=3'' when ''y=0'', and ''x=1'' when ''y=2''. This gives two more critical points (1,2) and (3,0).

Considering the full system, we have
:<math>\begin{pmatrix} x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3x - x^2 - xy \\ y + xy - y^2 \end{pmatrix}</math>

Labelling <math>\displaystyle f(x,y) = 3x - x^2 - xy</math> and <math>\displaystyle g(x,y) = y + xy - y^2</math>, the Jacobian of the system at <math>(x,y)</math> is

:<math>J = \begin{pmatrix} f_x & f_y \\ g_x & g_y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 - 2x - y & -x \\ y & 1 + x - 2y \end{pmatrix}</math>

The Jacobian evaluated at the critical points gives us information about the local stability of the critical points.


=== At ''(x,y) = (0,0)'' ===

:<math>J(0,0) = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}</math> which has eigenvalues of +1 and +3. Thus (0,0) is an unstable node (both eigenvalues are real and positive).


=== At ''(x,y) = (0,1)'' ===

:<math>J(0,1) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} </math> which has eigenvalues of +2 and -1 (being lower triangular, the eigenvalues are the diagonal entries). As the eigenvalues are real and of opposite sign, (0,1) is a saddle point.


=== At ''(x,y) = (3,0)'' ===

:<math>J(3,0) = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & -3 \\ 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}</math> having eigenvalues of -3 and +4 (the matrix is upper triangular and its eigenvalues are the diagonal entries). We thus have (3,0) is a saddle point.


=== At ''(x,y) = (1,2)'' ===

:<math>J(1,2) = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix}</math>. The eigenvalues satisfy the characteristic polynomial <math>\lambda^2 + 3 \lambda + 4 = 0</math> so <math>\lambda^\pm = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9 - 16}}{2} = -3/2 \pm \sqrt{7} i/2.</math> These eigenvalues have a nonzero imaginary part giving rise to a spiral/ellipse. As there real components are negative, we have a stable spiral at (1,2).
statement_html:
Suppose the interaction between two species (\(x=x(t)\) is the â€œpreyâ€ while \(y=y(t)\) is the predator) can be modelled by the autonomous system:

\[\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{c} \frac{dx}{dt} = x\left(3-x-y\right) \\ \frac{dy}{dt} = y\left(1+x-y\right) \end{array} \right.\end{aligned}\]

(a) Determine all the critical points and classify their type and stability.
